description: Unified Dish Scoring Framework - Merges Anna's Hit List (performance) with Family Fit Framework

framework_philosophy.principle: Score dishes on BOTH what families actually do (performance) AND what works for families (fit)
framework_philosophy.anna_contribution: Performance metrics from Looker + surveys showing revealed demand
framework_philosophy.family_fit_contribution: Family-specific factors critical for Dinneroo's positioning
framework_philosophy.why_unified: Anna's approach captures demand, ours captures fit. Together = complete picture of dish attractiveness.

performance.description: How well is this dish actually performing? (Anna's behavioral metrics)

normalized_sales.description: Demand for dish, normalized for availability - prevents bias toward dishes in more zones

zone_ranking_strength.description: Consistency of demand across zones - dishes that rank highly everywhere are more universally appealing

scoring.5: #1 in 20%+ of zones OR top 5 in 60%+ of zones
scoring.4: #1 in 10%+ of zones OR top 5 in 40%+ of zones

deliveroo_rating.calculation: Average star rating on Family Dinneroo orders

repeat_intent.survey_question: How likely are you to order the same dish again?
repeat_intent.description: Forward-looking retention signal - will families come back for this?

satisfaction.description: How satisfied are families with this dish? (Blended survey signals)

meal_satisfaction.survey_question: How satisfied were you with the meal?
meal_satisfaction.description: Overall consumer satisfaction with the dish

kids_happy_rate.survey_question: How did your child(ren) react to the meal?
kids_happy_rate.description: Critical for Dinneroo - kids eating it = family success

family_fit.description: Does this dish work for Dinneroo's family positioning? (Family-specific factors)

kid_friendly.description: Kids will actually eat it - familiar flavours, not too spicy

scoring.5: Universally kid-friendly, mild by default, familiar presentation
scoring.4: Most kids will eat, familiar ingredients, appealing look
scoring.3: Some kids will eat with mild option or adaptation

fussy_eater_friendly.source: Dropoff Survey (1,037 mentions of fussy eaters as barrier)
fussy_eater_friendly.description: Mild options available, customisable for picky kids

scoring.5: Mild by default, universally appealing, no 'scary' ingredients
scoring.4: Mild option available, familiar ingredients throughout
scoring.3: Can be made mild on request
scoring.2: Some unfamiliar ingredients, may need adaptation
scoring.1: Spicy/complex by nature, difficult to adapt

balanced_guilt_free.description: Parents feel good serving it on a Tuesday - fits 'balanced midweek meal' positioning

scoring.5: Clearly balanced meal, visible protein + veg + carbs, grilled/healthy
scoring.4: Mostly balanced, some vegetables included, not too heavy
scoring.3: Neutral - can go either way depending on presentation
scoring.2: Indulgent but has some redeeming qualities
scoring.1: Pure treat/indulgence, not a balanced meal

scoring.4: Sharing platters or 4 individual portions work well
scoring.3: Can be ordered in quantities for 4
scoring.2: Individual portions only, awkward for family
scoring.1: Single-serve only, not suitable for family sharing

customisation.description: Individual preferences can be accommodated within the order

scoring.1: No customisation, take it or leave it

opportunity.description: What's the growth potential for this dish? (Demand signals + availability)

dish_suitability_rating.description: Survey-driven consumer appeal - frequency of consumption, difficulty to cook at home, desire to see on app
dish_suitability_rating.note: Anna's measure - provides early insight into consumer appeal before behavioral data exists

open_text_requests.description: Explicit unmet demand - number of times dish is mentioned when customers asked what they'd like to see
open_text_requests.note: Anna's measure - captures latent demand for dishes not currently available or underrepresented

availability_gap.description: How much room for expansion? Dishes available in few zones have more growth potential

scoring.5: Available in <20% of zones (high expansion potential)

availability_gap.note: Inverse scoring - less availability = more opportunity

tier_classification.description: Classify dishes into priority tiers based on composite score

tier_1_must_have.label: Must-Have
tier_1_must_have.description: Essential dishes for every MVP zone
tier_1_must_have.action: Prioritize availability, expand to all zones

tier_2_should_have.label: Should-Have
tier_2_should_have.description: Important dishes that strengthen zone offering
tier_2_should_have.action: Recruit where gaps exist, promote where available

tier_4_monitor.label: Monitor
tier_4_monitor.description: Below threshold - may need improvement or removal
tier_4_monitor.action: Investigate underperformance, consider removing from bundles

quadrant_analysis.description: Plot dishes on Performance vs Family Fit to identify action quadrants

star.action: EXPAND - These are proven winners, get them in more zones

potential.action: INVESTIGATE - Good fit but not selling. Marketing issue? Availability issue?

cash_cow.action: MAINTAIN - Selling well but may not fit positioning. Don't expand aggressively.

open_text_analysis: Dish request counts from survey open-text

weight_rationale.why_performance_35: Behavioral data is the strongest signal of actual demand. Anna's normalized metrics prevent availability bias.
weight_rationale.why_satisfaction_20: Satisfaction predicts retention. Kids happy rate is critical for Dinneroo specifically.
weight_rationale.why_family_fit_30: Dinneroo's positioning is 'balanced midweek family meals' - fit factors ensure we stay on-brand.
weight_rationale.why_opportunity_15: Forward-looking signals help identify growth opportunities, but shouldn't override proven performance.
